IN THE HOPPER: In surveying the deadly wildfires in California, President Donald Trump promised $500 million in the farm bill for forest management and stressed the importance of working with environmental groups to improve forest maintenance.

— The Agriculture Department and FDA have a plan for splitting up regulatory authority over cell-based protein products, but lawmakers who control the agencies’ budgets have other ideas. A year-end budget battle could determine who wins out.

— On tap today: The Environmental Working Group plans to release data on early recipients of USDA’s tariff-relief program, including names and dollar figures.

— Beyond the soda-tax wars: There’s a broader effort to keep states from enacting food and nutrition laws — and to shield businesses from liability in obesity claims.

FOREST FIRES AND THE FARM BILL: Trump took stock of the charred California landscape this weekend, pointing to rapid movement in farm bill talks and repeatedly referencing new forest management funds in the bill as one thing the federal government could do to limit future wildfire damage.

“In the farm bill, we’re putting quite a bit of money — about $500 million — in the farm bill for management and maintenance of the forests beyond this area,” Trump said Saturday in Chico, Calif. “That will be in the farm bill. We just put it in. The farm bill is moving along pretty rapidly for our great farmers. But we have a new category and that’s management and maintenance of the forests. It’s very important.”

MA had an early look last month at the heated debate between House Republicans and Senate Democrats over forestry provisions, including changes to wildfire-prevention efforts. House Agriculture Chairman Mike Conaway said on Friday that farm bill negotiators had not resolved forestry provisions, according to reports.

— The “raking” flap: In Paradise, Calif., Trump claimed Finland avoids devastating wildfires by diligently “raking” its forest floors. (Finland’s president says he never discussed raking with Trump, per POLITICO’s Quint Forgey.) California Gov. Jerry Brown, a Democrat who has sparred frequently with Trump, suggested the state needs to do more to thin its forests, the Sacramento Bee writes.

Trump’s claim that the farm bill is moving along rapidly largely checks out. House Agriculture leaders sounded bullish Friday about closing in on a deal with the Senate, your host reported. Conaway and ranking member Collin Peterson said they sent their Senate counterparts an offer after reaching agreement on all 12 titles.

Farm bill marathon: Committee staff worked through the weekend to help bring negotiators closer to agreement on the sweeping legislation, but they were tight-lipped about how much progress was made. Peterson apparently told a group of Minnesota farmers that a final deal on the House side could be reached as soon as Monday.

HAPPY MONDAY, NOV. 19! Welcome to Morning Ag, where your host is cooking the Thanksgiving turkey this year and could use some suggestions from seasoned pros. Send news and turkey tips to rmccrimmon@politico.com and @ryanmccrimmon, and follow the whole team @Morning_Ag.

USDA, FDA WANT SHARED POWER OVER CELL-BASED MEATS: When the Agriculture Department and FDA released plans for sharing regulatory jurisdiction over cell-based meats, their joint statement Friday included a brushback pitch to Congress: The Trump administration “does not believe that legislation on this topic is necessary.”

Republican and Democratic appropriators support giving USDA full authority to regulate the budding sector — and the House Agriculture-FDA spending bill, H.R. 5961 (115), which could be approved during the lame-duck session, includes language to that effect.

Trump administration officials have asked lawmakers to keep the House provision out of a final version of the appropriations bill while USDA and FDA sort out a regulatory framework.

Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue and FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb tried to get out in front of Congress by releasing details of their proposed joint regulatory framework, a move that followed a two-day joint public meeting in October.

Here’s how it would work: FDA would oversee early stages of the process, like cell collection and cell banks. USDA would then handle oversight of food production and labeling. Your host has more details on the arrangement and the related appropriations fight.

— The Good Food Institute, a nonprofit that supports the alternative protein sector, praised Perdue and Gottlieb for “clearing the way for a transparent and predictable regulatory path forward.”

— Companies that are working on cell-based protein products, like Memphis Meats and JUST, are also backing the proposed division of responsibility (which is similar to what Memphis Meats and the North American Meat Institute suggested in a joint letter to Trump in August).

— Memphis Meats CEO Uma Valeti said the plan “plays to the respective strengths of both USDA and FDA, while continuing to foster innovation and assure a safe and reliable food system.”

— The National Cattlemen’s Beef Association said giving USDA “primary jurisdiction over the most important facets of lab-produced fake meat” is “a step in the right direction, but there is still a lot of work to do on this issue.”

Approps question TBD: It remains to be seen if House appropriators will drop their bid to give cell-based meat jurisdiction to USDA.

TRADE-AID PAYMENTS UNDER THE MICROSCOPE: The Environmental Working Group at noon today is set to make public the names of ag producers receiving payments through USDA’s trade-assistance package. The group filed a FOIA request in late September to obtain the names and addresses of trade-aid recipients — and how much money each is getting.

EWG’s disclosure is likely to cover a fraction of total recipients, since most of the $4.7 billion that USDA set aside for the first round of direct payments is still sitting in federal coffers. (Reuters reported last week that just $840 million has trickled out to farmers so far.)

— Issue to watch: EWG has frequently complained that city-dwellers who don’t live or work on farms often still receive farm subsidies. Today’s data dump is expected to show plenty of trade-aid payments flowing to residents of major metropolises like New York and San Francisco.

There’s been some backlash against large ag companies benefiting from other pieces of the trade-assistance package, like the $1.2 billion commodity purchase program.

USDA canceled a $240,000 contract with Smithfield Foods after public complaints that the Chinese-owned pork-processing giant was set to receive taxpayer funds that were intended to help U.S. farmers and ranchers suffering from Beijing’s retaliatory duties, our Catherine Boudreau reports. (Smithfield requested that the contract be terminated, and no funds had been transferred, according to USDA.)

STATE PREEMPTION LAWS UNDER FIRE: There’s a broad effort underway to limit state and local governments’ ability to enact food and nutrition policies like sugary drink taxes and nutrition labeling. A new study published in the American Journal of Preventive Medicine quantifies the trend: Between 2008 and March 2018, a dozen states enacted 13 preemption laws on food and nutrition. (Not included on this list: Washington state’s initiative to block all food and beverage taxes, which voters approved earlier this month.)

— There’s also been a push to limit industry liability in potential obesity claims: Between 2003 and 2013, 26 states passed so-called Commonsense Food Consumption Acts, the study found.

“The specific focus of all of these laws is to preempt lawsuits based on claims that a consumer’s weight gain, obesity, or associated health conditions resulted from long-term consumption of food,” the researchers write. Read the study here.

ROW CROPS

— NAFTA 2.0’s hard climb on the Hill: The new North American trade pact is drawing fire from the right and the left, Pro Trade’s Sabrina Rodriguez reports. Liberals say they want tougher environmental protections and higher labor standards in Mexico, while conservatives are protesting new protections in the deal for LGBT workers.

— APEC meeting ends without joint statement: A clash between the U.S. and China over the future of the WTO prevented this weekend's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Papua New Guinea from producing a joint statement for the first time since 1993 — a bad sign heading into Trump’s expected meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G20 gathering later this month, our Pro Trade colleagues report. The main sticking point was whether the statement should include a reference to WTO changes, Papua New Guinea Prime Minister Peter O’Neill said during a closing press conference.

— Rare trade criticism: China’s former chief trade negotiator criticized as ill thought-out Beijing’s decision to target U.S. soybeans, our content partners at the South China Morning Post report.

— CDC corrects record on farmer suicides: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention last week issued new data and retracted a widely cited 2016 report that mistakenly said farmers had the highest rate of suicide of any U.S. worker in 2012. After a data-entry problem was corrected, construction and “extraction” workers (like miners) had the highest suicide rate in 2012 and again in 2015, Pro Ag’s John Lauinger reports.

— Grassley chooses Senate Finance gavel: Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley will make the jump to the Finance Committee chairmanship, where he’ll play a major role in ushering the new North American trade pact through Congress. Sabrina Rodriguez has more on Grassley’s decision.

— Trade war spurs ag changes in China: The escalation of tariffs between the U.S. and China has prompted Beijing to take steps to modernize its agriculture industry, which is dominated by small farms with low crop yields. The Chinese government plans to build 254 “strong agricultural industrial towns” and, potentially, lift a ban on genetically modified seeds. The Wall Street Journal has the story.

— Misleading studies behind chlorpyrifos approvals? New analysis of the decades-old, industry-sponsored tests of the insecticide chlorpyrifos found discrepancies between the results and what Dow Chemical Co. had reported back then to the EPA, writes Environmental Health News.

— The initial tests have long been cited in continued government approvals of chlorpyrifos, which has been linked to learning disabilities in children. (The Trump administration recently appealed a federal court ruling that EPA must ban the chemical.) Here’s the research.

— Democrat wins Florida ag commissioner race: Nikki Fried, a South Florida attorney, defeated Republican Matt Caldwell after two rounds of recounts in the race for agriculture commissioner. The Miami Herald has this deep dive on Fried’s victory.

THAT’S ALL FOR MA! See you right here tomorrow. WHAT THEY’RE SAYING ACROSS THE POND — Your MC host co-moderated a panel in Brussels on cyber diplomacy over the weekend, and boy are the Belgians good at breakfast and churches. But, more importantly, the entire POLITICO EU conference offered some meaningful insights on subjects of interest to cyber readers everywhere.

— The Paris agreement: Last week, Paris announced a broad call for improving cybersecurity, and more than 300 governments and organizations signed on to it. Some critics observed that it didn’t require concrete action. Still, most of the panel thought it was a positive development. “It's the first instance actually where I think we have non-governmental actors involved in the conversation very explicitly, both private sector and civil society organizations, subscribing to certain principles,” said Patryk Pawlak, Brussels executive officer for the EU Institute for Security Studies. “It's a very important shift.”

Christopher Painter, the former State Department cyber coordinator and currently a commissioner on the Global Commission on the Stability of Cyberspace, said the agreement “was an aggregator of a lot of things that already existed. It didn't really break new ground.” But there’s value in what it aggregated, as it drew on the work of Painter’s commission and others. The “high-level attention” is good, too, Painter said. None of the panelists took my bait on commenting on the U.S. not enlisting, but one top official suggested afterward that it was simply a matter of President Donald Trump being angry at French President Emmanuel Macron that day, given their clashes the weekend prior.

— Russia attribution: Last month, a number of nations joined arms in pointing the finger at Russia for a series of cyberattacks in a rare show of widespread unity in “naming and shaming” the Kremlin, although some sat out the fight. But with the exception of U.S. indictments, the resulting punishments have been minimal. That doesn’t mean they aren’t in the works, the panelists said. “I think it was an unprecedented view of unity,” said Carmen Gonsalves, head of international cyber policy for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the Netherlands. “Sanctions cannot be applied without a very careful process and not overnight.”

The “reputational damage” of that naming and shaming “cannot be entirely discarded or underestimated,” said Antonio Missiroli, assistant secretary general for emerging security challenges at NATO. Still, “The risk of escalation is there when it comes to retribution. We do have to be very careful.” Painter said in this case and others, “I do think it's a missed opportunity if we do the attribution and don't follow up with action very quickly.” Added Painter: “Deterrence means ‘timely’ and ‘credible.’” Nations are getting better at this, he said, but still have a ways to go.

— Election security: Europe will probably move toward certified products in the election security supply chain, said Gerhard Schabhüser, vice president for Germany’s Federal Office for Information Security. Unfortunately, that might not be enough, said Uku Särekanno, deputy director general and director of cyber security for the Information System Authority of Estonia. “You don't know about each and every tiny bit of the process where something is produced by a third party and how it's put together,” said Särekanno, who added that the supply chain was his “key concern” with election security. “Vulnerabilities emerge even if they’re certified.”

Too few people in the election world grasp the nature of the threat, said John Graham-Cumming, the chief technology officer for CloudFlare. “They don't grok that they are at risk as part of this overall system,” he said. And Julian King, European Commissioner for the Security Union, said cybersecurity of elections is an area where nations needed to collaborate more.

HAPPY MONDAY and welcome to Morning Cybersecurity! I miss Jason Williams. Happy birthday. Send your thoughts, feedback and especially tips to tstarks@politico.com, and be sure to follow @POLITICOPro and @MorningCybersec. Full team info below.

STATE OF THE STATE DEPARTMENT — The House Foreign Affairs Committee will probe the State Department’s failure to create a cyber bureau and the Trump administration’s cyber diplomacy agenda when Democrats take over in January. Ranking member Eliot Engel, who is expected to becoming the panel’s chairman in the 116th Congress, is “disappointed … about the lack of progress the State Department made in standing up the cyber bureau,” a Democratic congressional staffer told MC. Under retiring Chairman Ed Royce, the panel approved — and the House later passed — a bill, H.R. 3776, codifying an elevated cyber diplomacy office. Once Engel takes over, “the topline goal” will be ensuring that “the United States has a strong leadership role in cyberspace going forward internationally,” said the Democratic staffer, who added that the Trump administration’s “lack of a plan merits significant oversight right now.”

The State Department currently has a team of cyber and internet policy experts in the Economic Bureau, led by Deputy Assistant Secretary Rob Strayer. The Democratic congressional staffer said those experts were working hard but were “currently not empowered by senior leadership within the State Department at all.” The staffer also pointed to apparent “confusion and disagreement” among department leaders “about what cyber diplomacy even entails,” which they said was “concerning from an oversight perspective.” Expect panel Democrats to continue talking to Stayer, whether at public hearings or in private briefings, the staffer said.

Look for the Foreign Affairs Committee to hold country-specific hearings about the cyber threats from adversaries like Russia, China, North Korea and Iran — especially the former. “The priority … will be oversight of the decisions the administration has made,” the staffer told MC, “and I think at the forefront of that is oversight over the administration’s interactions with Russia,” with cybersecurity “a key part of that.”

The panel will also probe State’s own cybersecurity and IT practices. Democrats are “very concerned” about the agency’s low Federal Information Security Management Act scores and want to ensure that State’s cloud migration plans prioritize cybersecurity, according to the staffer. In addition, Democrats will scrutinize U.S. Cyber Command’s offensive operations. “Our committee has jurisdiction over war powers,” the staffer said. The panel wants to ensure that “the checks and balances … are maintained as we look at potential” cyber operations.

RUSSIA

STATE DEPARTMENT, CONTINUED — The State Department late last week confirmed an attempt by hackers to penetrate its networks. "The Department is aware of the recent malicious cyber event involving the spoofing (impersonation) of a Department employee reported by U.S. cybersecurity firm FireEye,” the department said in a statement. “No Department networks were compromised by this malicious cyber attempt." FireEye and CrowdStrike both said the attack looks similar to past work by APT29, the Russian government-connected hacking group also known as Cozy Bear, although both are working to solidify that attribution. Kaspersky Lab also attributed the campaign to APT29. MC first reported many of the details of the campaign.

NRMC A TO Z — Senior Department of Homeland Security officials briefed reporters late last week about the status of the new National Risk Management Center and how the department is working with industry to identify the country’s most important technology and processes — what it calls “national critical functions” — and decide how best to protect them given their varying levels of risk. Here’s some of what they said on the sidelines of a U.S. Chamber of Commerce event:

— DHS doesn’t have enough personnel to analyze every critical system, so the department is trying to help operators assess their own systems. The newly renamed Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency will have approximately 2,000 employees, “so we have to look at what those automated tools are” and “how can we do remote capabilities,” said CISA Director Chris Krebs.

— The agency has given itself until the end of the year to work with industry to identify the country’s national critical functions. Beginning in early 2019, Krebs said, “we’ll be prioritizing” which ones to defend and how. DHS expects different interactions with different critical infrastructure sectors. “Those that are more mature tend to want to work with us more,” he said. “Coincidentally, that maturity is also associated with the highest risk.”

— The NRMC’s public-private partnerships will make it difficult to adhere to strict deadlines for completing tasks, because the government can’t force private companies to meet their goals. “The enforceability through public-private partnerships is one of those intrinsic challenges,” Krebs said. But he expressed confidence that the partnerships would succeed. “The level of participation we have in the [supply chain] task force alone shows that industry wants to do this with us,” he said. “They’re not in here to waste their time. They’re not in this to waste our time.” Large companies, he said, have told him that they have teams of 10 people “sitting here ready to go and work on this effort.”

— After identifying the country’s national critical functions, DHS and the private sector will start discussing what level of protection each function needs. NRMC Director Robert Kolasky offered an example: Virtually every industry relies on Positioning, Navigation and Timing data, usually provided through GPS satellites. But not every industry needs the same level of precision. The financial sector measures transactions in microseconds, but other sectors may be OK measuring things in minutes. “It’s a perfect example of, we know it’s something that’s important, but let’s figure out to what extent,” Kolasky said. “Because if I just say it’s important and we should invest more, you’re wasting money on risk mitigation.”

DMARC SUNLIGHT — The Global Cyber Alliance is releasing an interactive tool today to help consumers evaluate email domains to see if they’re secure from spoofing by using the Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance standard. The DMARC Leaderboard contains information on half a million domains now, and the Alliance plans to get to 10 million by the first quarter of 2019. “Sunlight remains the best disinfectant,” said Philip Reitinger, president and CEO of GCA. “The GCA DMARC Leaderboard offers a way to compare countries, sectors and companies as to their progress in deploying email spoofing protections, and we hope it helps lead to universal adoption of DMARC.”

LEARNING TO FLY — Cybersecurity ranks as one of the top eight management challenges facing the Transportation Department in fiscal 2019, a newly released inspector general report concludes. Many of DOT’s cybersecurity woes are old. For instance, a 2016 audit found the Security Operations Center did not have access to all departmental systems to monitor them for security incidents, and it still doesn’t. If anything, it seems to be getting less secure, not more: a 2017 audit found 4,529 open security weaknesses, more than the 4,286 the IG reported a decade ago. It also has yet to implement some years-old congressional mandates on aviation cybersecurity, the IG found.

DOUBLE DUTCH — The Homeland Security Department’s science wing and its Dutch counterpart late last week awarded $2.5 million to five organizations to create fixes for distributed denial of service attacks and better secure industrial controls. “The capabilities developed by the joint research teams will benefit both countries today and into the future. We hope this is the first of many joint ventures with our international partners,” said William Bryan, who’s performing the duties of the undersecretary for science and technology.

RECENTLY ON PRO CYBERSECURITY — Sen. Rand Paul wants more info on metadata before he’ll let Trump's pick to be the nation's top counterterrorism official move forward. … Criminal charges have apparently been filed against WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange. …Huawei announced it’s opening a “security lab” in Germany, amid concerns in Berlin that the company poses risks to national security.

TWEET OF THE DAY — It’s not that bad an explanation, really.

QUICK BYTES

A STEP FOR THE COMMON MAN (AND WOMAN): CommonWell Health Alliance described its ability to connect any of its members to the Carequality framework Friday as a crucial step toward interoperability. And without a doubt it is encouraging. But don’t take the “golden spike” symbolism too far. Just a couple of years after tycoon Leland Stanford drove the ceremonial last spike linking the Central Pacific and Union Pacific railroads in Utah in 1869, you could take a train from coast to coast. Getting sensible data from any point in the health care system to another may take a little longer.

CommonWell’s vendors — Cerner, Allscripts, eClinicalWorks, Meditech, et. al. — still haven’t signed up the majority of their provider clients. Once they do, of course, they’ll be able to share consolidated care documents -- but even that’s not enough to produce First Class service along the rails. …

But there could be immediate benefit to providers and hospitals that use smaller vendors — say, Greenway Health practices, or critical access hospitals using Evident — when their patients are seen in an Epic hospital (Epic, of course, isn’t part of CommonWell). “There’s huge value for those type of hospitals because CommonWell wasn’t giving them good access to the Epic site,” says CommonWell executive director Jitin Asnaani.

The announcement “is a historic event that opens the technical door for almost any provider to exchange patient records with little or no cost or effort,” but “will only make a difference if everyone joins,” said Coray Tate, vice president for interoperability at Klas Research. “The onus now shifts to the vendors and their customer bases to figure out how to join en masse.”

The agreement should tell ONC that industry is moving toward a “single onramp” to interoperability even without government actions like TEFCA, Asnaani said. “My hope is that it demonstrates to ONC they should not try to start from scratch” with TEFCA. “But I also hope it puts wind in their sails.”

Tweet of the Day: Stefan Kertesz @StefanKertesz The PDMP debate short take: (a) I use one & sometimes find it helpful, but (b) if you don't have care resources or relevant training in pain/addiction, then PDMP becomes a "tool for getting rid of liabilities"(i.e. people). FYI: "getting rid of liabilities" is _not_ health care!

Welcome to Monday morning eHealth, where we’re back from three days in Boston, enriched with better understanding of deep learning, Random Forest, and health IT options for the elderly. Send tips to aallen@politico.com or, more securely, to arthurallen202 on Signal. Or pass along knowledge via Twitter @ravindranize, @arthurallen202, @dariustahir, @POLITICOPro, @Morning_eHealth.

TELEMEDICINE USE INCREASES IN MEDICARE, BUT NOT DRAMATICALLY: The report that CMS delivered to Congress on Friday, fulfilling a duty under the 21st Century Cures Act, found an increase of telemedicine use of about 50 percent in fee-for-service Medicare from 2014 to 2016. Most of the coverage was for chronic conditions and mental health in rural areas, as before. Groups like Health IT Now and the Alliance for Connected Care are pushing for legislation that will make the service more generally available to Medicare beneficiaries.

… CMS's analysis of claims data during the period found about 90,000 of the 35 million Medicare fee-for-service beneficiaries used telehealth services. The report, which didn’t conceal Administrator Seema Verma’s bullish position on telemedicine, said that if just 1 percent of face-to-face encounters were switched to telehealth services already covered by Medicare, there would be a 13-fold increase in telehealth usage.

… Reimbursement rules limiting originating sites to clinics in rural areas are the greatest barrier to wider adoption, sayeth the report.

FINANCE GAVEL TO MOVE FROM ONE WRINKLED HAND TO ANOTHER: With Sen. Orrin Hatch, 84, retiring, Sen. Chuck Grassley, 85, will take over chairmanship of the Finance Committee, thereby gaining jurisdiction over a fair chunk of health care. Among other things, notes Darius Tahir, Grassley has been a longtime advocate for unique device identifiers — the FDA recently put off requiring them for Class I and unclassified devices until 2022 — and the Open Payments database, which shows the dough flowing to doctors from pharma and device companies.

YELP BEATS CMS: At least when it comes to rating nursing homes, the humble crowd-sourced review site may be getting at something more important to residents and their loved ones than CMS’ Nursing Home Compare, which has been around since 1998. That was the conclusion of research presented during a poster session Friday at the annual science conference of the Gerontological Society of America in Boston. The research, from the University of Southern California’s school of gerontology, found a big disconnect in the ratings done by CMS and Yelp. While the Yelp results weren’t statistically significant — some were based on as few as five reviews of a facility — the reviewers were consistently most interested in qualities that CMS doesn’t measure, such as caring attitudes, responsiveness and cleanliness.

… CMS’ Nursing Home Compare — also known as the 5-Star Rating — includes measures of staff size and health inspections, but it doesn’t track customer satisfaction, and there is literature suggesting that nursing homes can game some of its measures, said Heather Davila, who presented related research she and colleagues conducted at the University of Minnesota. “The 5-Star Rating looks at a small set of measures based on an assessment that is a response to complaints or based on an inspection of a few days a year,” she said. (This item was supported by a journalism fellowship from the GSA, the Journalists Network on Generations and the Silver Century Foundation)

GOOGLE HALTING SMART LENS DIABETES PROJECT: The project, which Verily announced in 2014 in partnership with Novartis, put sensors on contact lenses to measure glucose levels for people living with diabetes. But the company has decided to put the research on hold, Chief Technology Officer Brian Otis said in a blogpost Friday evening. The Smart Lens was developed to sense and transmit data to the eye and is also useful following cataract surgery, Otis wrote, but researchers found it difficult to get reliable correlations of tear and blood glucose levels because of “interference from biomolecules in tears.” That raised questions about whether the device could get FDA approval. Work on the smart contact lenses and intraocular lenses will continue, Otis said.

… Verily is also working with Dexcom on miniaturized continuous glucose monitors and with Onduo, a joint venture with Sanofi that has a diabetes management platform.

CMS ANNOUNCES AI CONTEST: How can AI help transform health care delivery and improve health outcomes? CMS has no idea, but will hold a competition next year to find out. More details here.

BIG IT CONTRACT CHALLENGE: Cognosante and GDIT have challenged Booz Allen’s $1 billion IT Operations and Services contract, which supports the VA’s office of information and technology on a variety of projects. This is not to be confused with Booz Allen’s $750 million change management contract with the VA for the EHR modernization project with Cerner….

SHIFTING WHITE HOUSE: President Donald Trump continues to let Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen twist in the wind. In an interview broadcast Sunday with Fox News' Chris Wallace, Trump said he wants Nielsen to be "much tougher on the border — much tougher, period. We'll see what happens there.”

“It's far from an unfamiliar plight,” observed POLITICO’s Eliana Johnson Friday. “Past officials including former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, former chief of staff Reince Priebus and former national security adviser H.R. McMaster were all treated to weeks or months of reports about their impending doom before their official dismissal, with Trump pawing at them like a cat toying with wounded mice.” Watch the interview here and read Johnson here.

PRESSURE IS ON PENSIONS: The multiemployer pension supercommittee has only four working days left to come up with a bipartisan solution to shore up failing multiemployer pension plans, lest they bankrupt the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, which insures them. The committee hasn’t met since July. But a congressional aide assures Morning Shift that “work on a solution to the problems facing the multi-employer system is well underway.”

Pensioners aren’t buying it, and they’re starting to put pressure on the president. The Protect Our Retirees Earned Retirement coalition, chaired by former Rep. Connie Mack (R.-Fla.), bought an ad on Fox News Sunday that urged President Trump to demand Congress take action. Members of the Teamsters union gathered on Capitol Hill last week to urge passage of the Butch Lewis Act, which would shore up multiemployer pensions with low-interest federal loans that could be repaid over 30 years. Watch the ad here.

‘IT WILL GET WORSE’: Josh Gotbaum, a former PBGC director, warned in a Brookings essay last week that if Congress fails to act “the situation will get worse, and a lot sooner than people think.” Without a statutory fix, Gotbaum predicted there will be an “employer stampede” away from all multiemployer plans--even the healthy ones. More here.

IMMIGRATION POLICIES IN COURT: Two district court proceedings today on asylum access:

D.C., 10 a.m. EST: Attorneys with the American Civil Liberties Union will present arguments in Grace v. Sessions challenging a move by former-Attorney General Jeff Sessions to make it more difficult for victims of domestic violence and other crimes to receive asylum. More on the suit here.

San Francisco, 9:30 a.m. PST: ACLU lawyers will present arguments in East Bay Sanctuary Covenant v. Trump seeking an injunction to block the Trump administration's moves earlier this month to deny asylum to migrants who cross the border illegally. More on the suit here.

TRADE PARADE

CONSERVATIVES TAKE AIM AT NAFTA 2.0: A letter signed by 40 conservative lawmakers Friday urged President Trump to rescind a provision in the new North American trade pact that LGBT workers be protected from workplace discrimination, POLITICO’s Alexander Panetta and Lauren Gardner report.

"This is language that is going to cause a lot of people to reconsider their support of the trade agreement, and to the point that it may endanger the passage of the trade agreement unless something is done," Rep. Doug Lamborn (R-Colo.) told POLITICO in an interview. The Obama Justice Department interpreted the 1964 Civil Rights Act’s prohibition against sex-based workplace discrimination to bar discrimination against LGBT people, but under former Attorney General Jeff Sessions the Trump Justice Department revoked that policy. Appellate courts have split on the matter. More here.

Related read: “Trump's Mexico-Canada deal hits trouble in Congress,” from POLITICO.

TWO AMERICAS: What’s the social cost of Amazon’s decision to locate its new HQ2 (or HQs 2 and 3) in Long Island City and Crystal City, Va.? A new report out today from the Brookings Institution says that urban hubs such as San Francisco, Boston, and New York, accounted for “72 percent of the nation’s employment growth” since the 2008 financial crisis. Researchers Clara Hendrickson, Mark Muro, and William Galston write that smaller metro areas (50,000 to 250,000 people) contributed less than 6 percent of the nation’s employment growth since 2010. And employment “remains below pre-recession levels” in many rural communities (less than 50,000 people).

“In a very real way, the 2016 election of Donald Trump represented the revenge of the places left behind in a changing economy,” write Hendrickson, Muro, and Gallston. Policies that boost rural tech skills, access to capital, and access to broadband, among others, could tamp down the widening economic gap between rural and urban communities the report says. Read it here.

What we know about Trump’s taxes

PROGRAMMING NOTE: Morning Tax will not publish on Thursday, Nov. 22, and Friday, Nov. 23. The Morning Tax newsletter will resume publishing on Monday Nov. 26.

Editor’s Note: This edition of Morning Tax is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Tax subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro’s comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

A RETURN TO RETURNS: Sometime next year, we may know a lot more about President Donald Trump’s personal taxes. House Democrats are bent on getting their hands on his returns and some want to publicly air them. While it’s true that Trump’s tax practices are largely a black hole to the public, some information has come out about them in dribs and drabs. Now seems like a good time to catch up on what we know.

Zero income taxes: Trump paid no federal income taxes in 1978 and 1979, and apparently none or next to none in 1991 and 1993, the Washington Post and POLITICO reported separately in spring 2016, based on records from New Jersey gaming regulators. He reported negative income for '78 and ’79. Casino and hotel losses were cited for the ‘90s.

The $916 million loss: Trump claimed nearly $1 billion in net operating losses in 1995, according to three pages of returns for that year from three different states that were anonymously sent to the New York Times in late 2015. The Times said the losses were so big that they could have wiped out Trump’s tax liability for the next 18 years, and our Brian Faler reported they amounted “to almost 2 percent of all such deductions claimed that year.”

An ‘edgy’ tactic: Trump avoided reporting hundreds of millions of dollars in taxable income from canceled debt in the early 1990s, the Times reported, by arguing that the income qualified for an exception that was at the time used by insolvent corporations. The maneuver was edgy but not unique, our Katy O’Donnell reported.

Rich guy, low rate: Trump paid an effective tax rate of about 25 percent in 2005, according to two pages of returns obtained by journalist David Cay Johnston.

A tangled web: Trump got at least $413 million (in today’s dollars) from his father in the 1990s, mostly by using tax dodges, the Times reported in an exhaustive expose last month.

Pretty patchy stuff, to be sure. At each turn, the revelations were expected to do major political damage to Trump. They didn’t. He rode them out, portraying them as examples of his financial savvy and playing to most Americans’ inherent dislike of taxes. Would things turn out any differently if Democrats get their hands on his returns and they are publicized? It depends. If they just show that Trump did everything he could to avoid taxes, probably not, even if he used legally dubious maneuvers. Most people have already made up their minds about whether Trump is a tax dodger and whether they care. If the information shines light on conflicts of interest or shows signs of entanglement with Russia and other foreign interests? Maybe.

IT'S MONDAY AND WE'RE OPEN FOR BUSINESS. We'll take leaks on Trump's taxes or what have you, at bfaler@politico.com, alorenzo@politico.com teckert@politico.com and bbecker@politico.com. You can also reach us on Twitter: @berniebecker3, @tobyeckert, @brianfaler, @aaronelorenzo,@POLITICOPro and @Morning_Tax.

IN CONGRESS

GRASSLEY’S BACK: Now that Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) has decided to claim the gavel at Senate Finance, what can we expect? More oversight, for one thing. “Whatever committee I’ve been on, I spend more time on oversight than I do on legislating. And I intend to keep that up,” Grassley recently told Tax Notes. “I only need one vote to do oversight — my own vote.” In the past, Grassley has scrutinized overseas tax shelters, the treatment of whistleblowers who report tax fraud, and tax-exempt organizations. "He'll look very broadly," Dean Zerbe, a former top tax aide to Grassley, told our Aaron Lorenzo.

If Grassley does do some legislating, it might include two provisions that he was unable to get into the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, H.R. 1 (115), that would clarify which rewards whistleblowers are entitled to and end double taxation of rewards. Various interests are also clamoring for corrections to the TCJA.

Grassley’s intended focus on oversight recognizes the difficulty of getting any major tax legislation through the next Congress given the split partisan control of the chambers. However, Grassley was known for working with Democrats on some key issues during previous stints as Finance chairman. “I appreciate his willingness to work across the aisle, and I know that his voice will be an important one in the 116th Congress,” said Rep. Richard Neal (D-Mass.), who is expected to be Ways and Means chairman. “I hope that the Senator and I will be able to work together to expand opportunity for American families."

In other Finance news, committee member Bill Nelson (D-Fla.) conceded that he’s lost his bid for re-election, becoming the panel’s third casualty of the midterms. Two of his colleagues, Sens. Claire McCaskill (D-Mo.) and Dean Heller (R-Nev.), also lost their seats.

DEMS SPLIT ON TAX RULE: House Democrats are squabbling over a provision in a draft of chamber rules for the next Congress that would require a three-fifths “supermajority” vote to raise income taxes on the lowest-earning 80 percent of taxpayers. (It would only take a simple majority to raise taxes on the highest-earning 20 percent.) Under Republican rules in force now, it takes a supermajority for any income tax increase. The Democratic proposal has the support of House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and Neal, but not everyone in the caucus likes the idea.

“Some liberal Democrats said that if the party limits its own ability to raise taxes, it could make it harder for the House to adopt policies that could require tax increases, including a Medicare-for-all health program or a plan for tuition-free state colleges and universities,” the Washington Post reported. Some House Democratic aides noted that the requirement could be waived on a case-by-case basis by the Rules Committee.

AMAZON EFFECT: Two groups that oppose tax extenders legislation that Congress may take up in the coming weeks are using the massive subsidies given to Amazon by New York and Virginia to build their case. “Americans across the country, including lawmakers from both sides of the aisle, have rightfully decried the billions of dollars in corporate welfare given to Amazon,” Americans for Prosperity and Freedom Partners say in a letter they intend to send today to House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell. “Legislation like this rigs the system for the powerful and connected few at the expense of everyone else, and undermines what little trust Americans have in our political institutions and elected officials.”

STATE NEWS

BRING YOUR BRAIN TO MAINE: Some boosters of Opportunity Maine, a program that provides a tax credit to help residents pay off their student loans if they attend a state university, want to expand it to people who move to the state with college debt. They see it “as a key part of a strategy to bring more young people to to the state and keep them here,” the Bangor Daily News reported. Nate Wildes, the engagement director for the group that markets Opportunity Maine, “views the credit as a crucial tool to address the state’s aging workforce, as well as recent projections of stagnant job growth over the next eight years.” But some lawmakers are loath to tinker with the program, saying it’s complicated enough already.

HEADING TO COURT: A judge in Washington state ruled that plaintiffs can move forward with a suit that alleges the Seattle City Council violated the state’s open meeting law before its vote to repeal a “head tax” on large corporations. “Three lawyers sued the city alleging the council majority and Mayor Jenny Durkan violated state open meetings law by reaching an agreement before the vote,” the Associated Press reported.

INTERNATIONAL UPDATE

TAX PROTESTS IN FRANCE: At least 409 people were injured over the weekend in protests in France over tax increases on diesel fuel and gasoline. “Grassroots protesters, dubbing themselves ‘yellow jackets’ for the safety jackets French motorists are required to keep in vehicles for emergencies, paralyzed traffic by blocking roads around the country Saturday,” the Associated Press reported. “Blockades were counted at 150 scattered locations Sunday, [Interior Minister Christophe] Castaner told RTL radio.”

MEANWHILE, IN GERMANY: Economy Minister Peter Altmaier called for tax cuts to boost economic growth after the German economy experienced its first contraction in three years. “Altmaier, a member of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s governing conservatives, said he was focused on cutting high German corporate taxes following tax cuts in the United States, Britain and soon France,” Reuters reported, citing an interview that Altmaier gave the Welt am Sonntag newspaper.

DID YOU KNOW?

A new front in the China trade war

With help from Doug Palmer

PROGRAMMING NOTE: Morning Trade will not publish on Thursday, Nov. 22 and Friday, Nov. 23. Our next Morning Trade newsletter will publish on Monday, Nov. 26. Please continue to follow Pro Trade issues here.

Story Continued Below

Editor’s Note: This edition of Morning Trade is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Trade subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro’s comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

ON TAP TODAY: The Trump administration today begins a fast-track comment process for rules aimed at restricting the export of critical technologies. The U.S. and China clash over a final statement at this past weekend’s APEC summit, a bad sign for talks at the G-20. Trump faces a tough road ahead for his new NAFTA deal as lawmakers on the left and right start picking apart the final pact. Start here:

A NEW FRONT IN THE CHINA TRADE WAR: The Trump administration will make its next big move towards China by opening a comment process today for a major new rule that would restrict exports of emerging and critical technology.

The rule will open a new front against Beijing as part of legislation increase scrutiny of transactions by U.S. companies with foreign firms and to limit exports of key U.S. “dual-use” technologies -- ones that have both commercial and military applications.

What could result: The rule will implement portions of the Export Control Reform Act, which was passed Congress in August as part of a broader defense bill that included a major overhaul of U.S. investment screening procedures. The legislation allows the Trump administration to cite national security to control exports of goods or technology that may not necessarily have a military use but could have economic or competitive advantages.

The executive branch usually has the authority to define a national security risk, but previous administrations have generally kept export controls narrowly focused on preventing adversarial countries from gaining a military advantage.

Key sectors: The areas identified as essential to the national security of the U.S. have a lot of overlap with technology that China is aiming to boost through its Made in China 2025 initiative and other programs. The 14 categories include biotechnology; artificial intelligence; microprocessor technology; robotics; advanced materials, among others. It also leaves open the possibility of other categories of technology being added.

Sped-up timeline: The effort will provide only 30 days for what one former senior Commerce Department official calls the start of one “the most complex, intellectually challenging, and economically significant effort to identify simultaneously multiple disparate categories of undefined emerging technologies for non-specific national security concerns.” Most routine notice and comment processes provide at least a 60-day window for public input.

“This period is not only over the holiday season, but also in the heart of the fourth quarter when company engineers, researchers, sales staff, management, and other professionals are focused on completing annual sales, shipment, and other goals,” said Kevin Wolf, who served as assistant secretary of Commerce for export administration under the Obama administration.

IT'S MONDAY, NOV. 19! Welcome to Morning Trade, where your host points out that the Washington, D.C., area is just three inches from hitting its wettest year on record. Anyone else grateful they got new gutters installed this year? Let me know: abehsudi@politico.com or @abehsudi.

JOIN POLITICO AND THE ATLANTIC COUNCIL’s Adrienne Arsht Latin America Center and its Global Business and Economics Program on Tuesday, Nov. 27 from 1:30 to 2:30 p.m. for a lunch discussion on the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement just days before its signing. The program will address important questions such as: What are the immediate and long-term consequences for U.S. and North American consumers? How might businesses adjust to the new deal? With a new Congress starting in January, what does the road ahead look like for USMCA ratification? Learn more here.

APEC MEETING ENDS WITHOUT JOINT STATEMENT: A clash between the United States and China over the future of the World Trade Organization prevented APEC leaders meeting in Papua New Guinea from agreeing on a joint statement for the first time since 1993, when the forum started holding leadership summits. The main sticking point was whether the statement should include a reference to WTO changes, Papua New Guinea Prime Minister Peter O’Neill of said during a closing press conference.

The U.S. wanted a tough statement demanding China no longer be treated as a developing nation under WTO rules, the Australian Financial Review reported. The world’s two largest economies also could not agree on language involving state-owned enterprises, which the United States believes have an unfair advantage over private firms because of the support they receive from China and other governments, the publication said.

The failure bodes badly for another leaders meeting, the G-20, on Nov. 30-Dec. 1, which both President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are scheduled to attend.

PENCE: TARIFFS WILL STAY UNTIL CHINA CHANGES BEHAVIOR: In a speech at the APEC CEO Summit, Vice President Mike Pence underscored the Trump administration’s determination to keep up the pressure on China.

“We’ve put tariffs on $250 billion in Chinese goods and we could more than double that number. But we hope for better. The United States though will not change course until China changes its ways,” Pence said.

U.S. vs. them: He also criticized China’s Belt-and-Road regional infrastructure initiative as a ploy to bind other countries to Beijing. “Know that the United States offers a better option. We don’t drown our partners in a sea of debt. We don’t coerce or compromise your independence. The United States deals openly, fairly. We do not offer a constricting belt or a one-way road.” Pence said.

The vice president, who met with a number of regional leaders during his trip abroad, also touted efforts to start trade talks with Japan. He hinted at negotiations with another APEC member, although he did not provide the name of the country. USTR has previously identified the Philippines as a candidate, despite concerns that many Democrats have about Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte’s human rights record.

XI: BELT-AND-ROAD NOT ‘A TRAP’: In his remarks to the same group, Xi rejected U.S. criticism of the five-year-old Belt-and-Road initiative.

“It is not designed to serve any hidden geopolitical agenda, it is not targeted against anyone and it does not exclude anyone. It is not an exclusive club that is closed to non-members, nor is it a ‘trap’ as some people have labeled it,” Xi said.

He also defended the rules-based world trading system developed by the U.S. and other Western powers in the decades after World War II, but called for changes to give developing countries a greater say. “Rules should be formulated by the international community, not in a might-is-right way. Once the rules are made, they should not be followed or bent as one sees fit, and they should not be applied with double standards for selfish agendas,” Xi said.

USMCA’S TOUGH ROAD AHEAD: Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle are raising concerns about the Trump administration’s new deal to overhaul NAFTA. On the left, members are expressing doubts on whether the pact’s labor and environment rules are tough enough. On the right, House members have raised alarm over new protections for LGBT workers.

If he’s blocked in Congress, Trump will be facing a major setback on an issue where he’s already been claiming credit for delivering on a campaign promise. He would be left with the unattractive choices of leaving the North American Free Trade Agreement in place, heading back to the negotiating table or pulling out of the deal entirely, as he’s repeatedly threatened.

"I warned the administration that they could find themselves in this trap of having some agreement and coming back to Congress as an afterthought expecting ratification," Rep. Ron Kind (D-Wis.) told POLITICO. "That's not how this place works." Pro Trade’s Sabrina Rodriguez has the full story here.

CHAMBER STILL ON THE USMCA FENCE: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce has yet to endorse the USMCA, nearly 50 days after the final part of the deal with Canada was struck. It outlined what it likes — and doesn’t like — about the agreement in a filing ahead of last week’s International Trade Commission hearing on the economic impact of pact.

On the plus side: The “agreement includes strong, positive provisions in a number of chapters, some of which surpass the quality achieved in any earlier U.S. trade agreement,” the Chamber said. Those include the chapters on digital trade, intellectual property, financial services, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, technical barriers to trade, competition policy, and state-owned enterprises.

“NAFTA’s positive status quo” was also maintained in many areas, the Chamber said.

Specifically, it remains trilateral, tariffs removed in the original agreement weren’t reimposed, and two key dispute settlement chapters weren’t eliminated as the Trump administration had originally proposed — although it would have been better if those chapters were reformed to make the dispute settlement function of the agreement work better, the Chamber said.

What it doesn’t favor: The group cited weakening of investment protections, the more restrictive auto rules of origin, the termination of government procurement coverage with Canada and the reduction of the same coverage with Mexico as disappointing.

It also said it wasn’t happy about the small increase in the “de minimis” level agreed by Canada and Mexico, which means many packages entering those two countries from the United States will still face significant border taxes.

The Chamber also called for an immediate lifting of tariffs on imports of steel and aluminum from Canada and Mexico—and those countries’ retaliation against more than $15 billion of U.S. exports.

CHAMBER TAKES ANTI-TARIFF MESSAGE TO THE AIRWAVES: To drive home its point, the Chamber is running ads on Washington radio stations through the end of the month (with a brief break over Thanksgiving) urging the administration to lift the tariffs.

That effort coincides with advertising the business group is doing on social media, which warn that approximately $500 million of America’s imports and exports are hit each week by Trump’s tariffs and Canada and Mexico’s retaliatory duties, “raising costs for U.S. manufacturers and consumers, hurting American exporters, and putting American jobs at risk.”

Don’t mess with Texas: Several Texas energy associations have urged the administration not to replace the steel and aluminum duties with a hard quota on imports because of the harm that would have on the state’s energy production.

“We are concerned such an action would create an artificial impediment to new oil and natural gas development activity in the Permian Basin in Texas as well as other regions throughout the country and impede the President’s ‘Energy Dominance’ agenda,” the groups said in a letter to U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross and White House chief economic adviser Larry Kudlow. “Hard quotas would stop the delivery of steel that is needed for Texas oil and natural gas development.”

The letter was signed by the Texas Oil and Gas Association, the Texas Alliance of Energy Producers, Texas Independent Producers & Royalty Owners Association, Permian Basin Petroleum Association, Texas Association of Manufacturers, Texas Association of Business, and the Association of Energy Service Companies.

INTERNATIONAL OVERNIGHT

— In an unusual move, China’s former chief trade negotiator criticized Beijing’s decision to target U.S. soybeans as ill-thought out, the South China Morning Post reports.

— The trade war is forcing China to spur efforts to modernize its farming sector, The Wall Street Journal reports.

— In an interview with POLITICO Pro, Energy Secretary Rick Perry said the U.S. is bringing its ‘A-game’ in efforts to export more U.S. energy products to Eastern Europe. More here.

— Washington trade advocacy groups have resorted to checking if large blocks of hotel rooms are unavailable for any signs of U.S.-China trade talks, CNN reports.

— As part of a news series, The New York Times examines several aspects of how China came to dominate economically, including in its approaches to the internet and in financing various projects.

FIRST UP FOR DEFAZIO: Incoming House Transportation Chairman Peter DeFazio is making plans to “drag” in DOT officials to testify about their slow-walking of transit grants — part of his top oversight priority next year, he told our Tanya Snyder. “Somehow DOT has constructed an unbelievably torturous new process for approving already-funded and -authorized transit projects, and they've clogged up the pipeline unbelievably,” the Oregon Democrat said. In the televised interview on C-SPAN's "Newsmakers," DeFazio indicated he doesn’t plan to smooth out his rough edges as chairman, calling Larry Summers a “jerk” and referring to “some idiot” at DOT. But he stood by his promise to work with President Donald Trump on infrastructure.

Climate kerfuffle: DeFazio has been one of several Democratic committee leaders pushing back on the idea that the new majority should create a standalone climate panel, and questioning the aggressive tactics of some newly elected Democrats. But that doesn’t mean it’s not an issue he wants to tackle next year, as it relates to transportation policy. He told MT on Friday: “When you look at how much carbon pollution there is due to congestion, wasted fuel, people sitting in traffic. It’s a major component of what we want to do in having more efficient movement of people and goods and more transit options for people.” DeFazio said while the issue is not his primary focus or jurisdiction, “we will be addressing components of contributions to climate change.”

IT’S MONDAY: Thanks for tuning in to POLITICO’s Morning Transportation, your daily tipsheet on all things trains, planes, automobiles and ports. Welcome to a shortened week, which will see millions of Americans take some form of transportation to get together with their loved ones and stuff themselves. Get in touch with feedback, tips or song lyric suggestions at smintz@politico.com or @samjmintz.

"I'm grateful for the laughter of children / The sun and the wind and the rain / The color of blue in your sweet eyes / The sight of a high ballin' train"

LISTEN HERE: Follow MT’s playlist on Spotify. What better way to start your day than with songs (picked by us and readers) about roads, rails, rivers and runways?

NELSON GOES DOWN: Commerce Committee ranking member Bill Nelson (D-Fla.) conceded to Republican Gov. Rick Scott Sunday, ending a bitter election which came down to a hand recount. The latest vote tallies had the Democrat down just 10,000 votes. Nelson's defeat could set off a scramble among Democrats, as it opens up their top spot on Commerce. There have been suggestions that current Energy Committee ranking member Sen. Maria Cantwell (D-Wash.), who would be first in line for the Commerce position, might make the switch. If she doesn't, Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) has the next shot.

Infrastructure

VICTORY LAP: A Friday morning meeting co-hosted by DeFazio and fellow infrastructure-happy Oregon Democrat Earl Blumenauer, billed as a “post-election wrap / new congress infrastructure agenda setting” gathering, generated “lots of enthusiasm and energy” from the standing-room-only crowd, according to one person who was present at the meeting. The lawmakers said they planned to hold hearings to gather ideas and recommendations to solve the country’s greatest infrastructure needs. Blumenauer, who serves on Ways and Means and is plotting to establish an infrastructure subcommittee, noted that the Republicans on that committee held only one hearing on transportation funding and finance in the eight years they were in charge.

The company, Build Your Dreams, is the only bus company that would be covered by the ban, which is the result of “a lobbying effort to protect the domestic freight rail industry from Chinese incursions,” Shaun Courtney writes. McCarthy has proposed language to exempt buses, which would allow BYD to earn future contracts with U.S. transit agencies, but he's set up a potential fight with senior Republican lawmakers in both chambers.

ON TRACK: Amtrak set revenue and earnings records for fiscal 2018, the company announced Friday — 31.7 million riders took trips on Amtrak, which it said was steady. Operating earnings were $193.7 million and total revenue was $3.38 billion. While the Northeast Regional and state-supported lines grew in ridership, long distance service was down nearly 4 percent due to a combination of factors. “We remain on track to cover total operating costs from ticket and other revenues in the next few years, which will allow us to focus funding on business improvements and expansion,” said board chairman Tony Coscia.

Lauderdale and West Palm Beach in May, is partnering with Richard Branson’s Virgin Group, the Miami Herald reports. The company will rename itself Virgin Trains USA, and plans to expand in Florida as well as creating a rail system between Las Vegas and Southern California.

Specifically, the legislation would create a $10 million credit subsidy through TIFIA. The two had previously included an amendment in the FAA reauthorization, which required DOT to report to Congress on whether the program’s low-cost financing mechanism could benefit airports. “By increasing access to capital financing, airports will be able to modernize passenger terminals, update runways, and complete important infrastructure projects quicker and more efficiently,” Perdue said in a statement.

fulltext:
The biggest sticking point in DeVos’ Title IX rules

With help from Kimberly Hefling and Caitlin Emma

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Education is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Education subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

PROGRAMMING NOTE: Morning Education will not publish on Thursday, Nov. 22 and Friday, Nov. 23. Our next Morning Education newsletter will publish on Monday, Nov. 26. Please continue to follow POLITICO Education issues here.

THE BIGGEST STICKING POINT IN DEVOS’ TITLE IX RULES: Administrators, advocates and attorneys are still poring over the massive set of proposed new rules for schools handling allegations of sexual harassment that the Education Department dropped on Friday. But one new element is already emerging as a major problem for many: A requirement added to the final version of the proposal that colleges hold a so-called “live hearing” — including cross-examination — during disciplinary proceedings.

— The new rule seems to be creating something of an alliance between advocates for sexual assault survivors, who say cross-examination can be retraumatizing for victims, and college officials, who say the rule is far too prescriptive and will force schools to mimic criminal trials in a way they aren’t prepared to do.

— “This would apparently permit one student to hire a highly paid legal pit bull to grill another student in a campus disciplinary proceeding,” said Terry W. Hartle, senior vice president of the American Council on Education, the leading higher education lobby group. “We will have serious concerns about such a provision … To the extent that they’re trying to turn a campus disciplinary proceeding into a courtroom, we are deeply troubled, because we aren’t courts.”

— The University of California — among the largest university systems in the nation — blasted the proposal, in large part because of the new live hearing requirement. “It’s inherently intimidating,” Suzanne Taylor, the UC system’s Title IX coordinator, told Morning Education. “This change more than almost any other will discourage complainants from coming forward.”

— The Education Department has stressed that the cross-examination in the hearings should be conducted by advisers or attorneys for the students, and not the students themselves. The students could also request to be in separate rooms during the hearing.

— That “alleviates the articulated concern of the trauma when someone is cross-examined directly by the person they believe sexually assaulted them, while still protecting those fundamental principles of fairness that go by the wayside when cross-examination is set aside,” said Joe Cohn, legislative and policy director at the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education, a civil liberties group that pushed to add the live hearing. “Cross-examination is the single most important engine toward the discovery of truth.”

— The proposal would ban the alternative used by some schools in which a single investigator probes allegations and makes a decision. That model is despised by groups like FIRE that say schools have trampled due process for the accused.

— The live hearing is likely one of the few elements of the new rules that schools will oppose. Schools could use a higher standard of evidence for discipline decisions related to sexual misconduct and offer mediation if both students agree to it, under the proposal. The rules also would significantly raise the bar for when schools are required to launch investigations. “The bigger picture is that there can be, I think, little doubt that these regulations, taken as a whole, will result in fewer sexual assault investigations at institutions,” Josh Richards, a higher education attorney, told Morning Education.

WELCOME TO THE WORKING WEEK. THIS IS MORNING EDUCATION. Tips? Feedback? Let me know: bwermund@politico.com or @BenjaminEW. Share event listings: educalendar@politicopro.com. And follow us on Twitter: @Morning_Edu and @POLITICOPro.

ON THE HILL

DEMOCRATS VOW TO FIGHT DEVOS’ PROPOSAL: Democrats say they will use their newfound control of the House to derail the proposed Title IX regulation. Rep. Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic leader and potential House speaker, promised “bold, immediate action” in a statement: “Our Democratic Majority, led by strong, diverse and dynamic women, will fight this cruel agenda.”

— Other Democrats promising to push back included Rep. Rosa DeLauro, (D-Conn.), in line to become the next chairwoman of the subcommittee that writes the Education Department budget, and Rep. Maxine Waters (D-Calif.), expected to become the next chairwoman of Financial Services.

— Ayanna Pressley, a newly elected Massachusetts Democrat, tweeted at DeVos that she is a campus sexual assault survivor and knows the "pain and fear survivors feel when they disclose": "Allow me to introduce myself. My name is Ayanna Pressley. I’ve just arrived in DC. I’m here to fight for survivors and hold your @usedgov accountable." More on that here.

TITLE IX

WHAT THE PROPOSAL COULD MEAN FOR K12 SCHOOLS: The Title IX proposed rules are largely associated with campus sexual assault, but Title IX has jurisdiction over K-12 schools, too. K-12 schools have dealt with both peer-on-peer sexual abuse and instances in which students are targeted by adults, such as teachers or coaches.

— “The implicit message from ED is that ‘we’re taking this whole sexual assault thing way too far,’ and we’re concerned the proposed guidance will both deter victims from coming forward and slow the momentum on education and prevention that school leaders have begun to build,” said Bob Farrace, a spokesman for the National Association of Secondary School Principals, in a statement.

— Under the proposal, K-12 schools would be allowed to have live hearings like those on college campuses, but it wouldn’t be a requirement. Lara Kaufmann, director of public policy at Girls Inc., said it appears unlikely schools would conduct such hearings, but it remains a possibility. “This is a particularly concerning part of the proposed regulations; it is easy to imagine how scary this could be for a young student,” Kaufmann said in a statement.

— Also, under the proposal, it appears if a teacher witnessed peer-on-peer sexual harassment or was told of it by one of the students involved, the school would be required to act. Catherine Lhamon, a civil right lawyer who oversaw the department’s Office for Civil Rights under President Barack Obama, questioned why it doesn’t include others in a school setting that students trust, such as a teacher’s aide or counselor. “When students have reported to a non-teacher, under this proposed regulation, the school would not have an obligation to act, and that will leave our children dramatically unsafe,” she said.

HIGHER EDUCATION

BLOOMBERG’S BIG GIFT: Former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg — who is weighing a 2020 presidential bid — plans to give $1.8 billion to Johns Hopkins University for undergraduate student financial aid. The gift to the private, Baltimore-based research institution allows it to permanently commit to providing “need-blind” admissions that weigh just merit in decisions — without considering a prospective student's finances. Bloomberg is a 1964 graduate of Johns Hopkins.

— Bloomberg’s gift represents the largest-ever donation to a U.S. college or university, according to the university and Bloomberg Philanthropies in a joint press release announcing the gift. A list of the largest university donations since 1967 published by the Chronicle of Higher Education appears to support that claim. Kimberly Hefling has more.

THURMOND WINS CALIFORNIA SUPERINTENDENT RACE: Tony Thurmond, a Democratic state legislator and former social worker backed by teachers unions, won the super close — and extremely costly — race to be California’s next education chief. Thurmond tweeted over the weekend that Marshall Tuck, the former president of a charter school organization, had called to congratulate him on winning the race. “I intend to be a champion of public schools & a Superintendent for all CA students,” Thurmond tweeted. The San Francisco Chronicle has more.

A CHALLENGE TO CHARTER SCHOOL FUNDING IN MISSISSIPPI: The nonprofit National Alliance for Public Charter Schools has filed a brief in a Mississippi lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of state and local funding for charter schools there.

— Mississippi has just a handful of charter schools after passing a law in 2013 that allows for their creation. The case challenging how they’re funded was first filed in July 2016 by a group of public school parents, represented by the Southern Poverty Law Center. A Mississippi chancery court earlier this year upheld the constitutionality of how charter schools are funded in the state and the parents appealed to the state Supreme Court. A decision in the case isn’t expected until next year.

— “Though charter schools are just beginning in Mississippi, they will provide an important educational benefit to Mississippi’s most disserved students,” NAPCS said in a statement. “Upholding the constitutionality of charter school funding in Mississippi keeps that ability to choose in place without any demonstrable harm to plaintiffs or to traditional public schools.” Read the brief.

REPORT ROLL CALL

— The Interior Department’s Inspector General has determined that officials at Haskell Indian Nations University in Lawrence, Kansas, did not consistently follow the university’s guidelines for handling complaints of misconduct and that Haskell’s administration inaccurately reported crime statistics in 2014 and 2015. Investigators al found that Haskell employees felt bullied and intimidated by the Haskell president. Read the report here.

Jeremy reports from Yuba County: “Two weeks after decisively winning an election framed as a referendum on President Donald Trump, California Gov.-elect Gavin Newsom met his foil for the first time on a smoke-stifled tarmac as the state burned.

Story Continued Below

From the moment Trump announced his visit, there was speculation as to whether he would be joined by Newsom, who has framed his imminent governorship as a counterweight to the president.

But as California reels from the deadliest wildfire in state history, Trump's visit affords the incoming governor an ability to rise above the animosity and work with the federal government when the need arises - even as he faces pressure from liberals at home to do the opposite.” Read the story in POLITICO here.

THE MIDTERMS

CISNEROS COMPLETES SWEEP: Democrat Gil Cisneros officially prevailed over GOP opponent Young Kim Saturday night, completing a Democratic sweep of congressional districts in the former Republican stronghold of Orange County.

A CAGOP TEARDOWN? With the Cisneros result official, it’s hard to imagine how the 2018 election could have gone worse for California Republicans — and as Carla gleans from a SoCal gathering of GOP politicos, the calls to start anew are getting louder:

-- RIP CAGOP: “In the wake of a near-political annihilation in California that has left even longtime conservative stronghold Orange County bereft of a single Republican in the House of Representatives, a growing chorus of GOP loyalists here say there’s only one hope for reviving the flatlining party: Blow it up and start again from scratch.

-- That harsh assessment comes as Republicans survey the damage from the devastation of a ‘blue tsunami’ in California which wiped out [six] GOP-held House seats ... while handing every statewide seat and a supermajority to the Democrats in both houses of the state legislature this week.

-- ‘I believe that the party has to die before it can be rebuilt. And by die — I mean, completely decimated. And I think Tuesday night was a big step,’ says veteran California GOP political consultant Mike Madrid. ‘There is no message. There is no messenger. There is no money. And there is no infrastructure.’” Read Carla Marinucci’s story in POLITICO here.

INSURANCE COMMISSIONER: Democratic state Sen. Ricardo Lara officially defeated party-less Steve Poizner, handing a victory to labor groups who backed Lara and throwing into question the emergent strategy of independent candidates like Poizner filling the void of successful statewide Republicans. Traditional GOP allies like the California Chamber of Commerce and the realtors backed Poizner, a former Republican, but he came up some 400,000 votes short.

STATE SUPE: State Assemblyman Tony Thurmond declared victory over Marshall Tuck, who called to concede; while the AP hasn't called this one yet, Thurmond leads by some 150,000 votes.

-- While this one is technically nonpartisan, the result is a big win for elected Democrats, allies like the California Teachers Association and the California Democratic Party, which heavily backed Thurmond. As the Sac Bee's Sophia Bollag writes, the result cements a second big loss for charter school advocates despite spending millions this cycle: Story

-- “Andrew Janz, back at work after 19 months of hard campaigning, takes a breath,” by the Fresno Bee’s Rory Appleton: “Janz spent 19 months on the campaign trail in his bid to topple 16-year Republican incumbent Congressman Devin Nunes. Janz and his staff raised $9.1 million, and they spent nearly every cent.” Story

CALIFORNIA ON FIRE

UPDATES:

CAMP FIRE (Butte County) -- 150,000 acres, 65 percent contained. 77 people are confirmed dead, and 993 remain missing.

WOOLSEY FIRE (Los Angeles, Malibu) -- 96,949 acres, 91 percent contained.

MORE FROM TRUMP’S VISIT: Newsom, Trump and Gov. Jerry Brown gave a little time to the traveling hacks on Air Force One, where the president continued to praise Newsom — whom he’s derided as a “clown” at campaign rallies — saying the incoming governor is “going to pick up the ball brilliantly. I have no doubt about it.”

-- Climate change remains the elephant in the room when it comes to the wildfires: Trump has not shown Brown’s readiness to underscore just how much a shifting climate is exacerbating risk and feeding a “new normal.” Their divergent responses on climate change:

BROWN: “Yes. Yes. We’ll let science determine this over a longer period of time,” on whether climate change is a factor.

TRUMP: “We didn’t discuss it.” (To which Jerry replied: “obliquely.”). “We have different views but maybe not as different as people think,” Trump continued. “Things are happening. Things are changing. And I think most importantly we’re doing things about — to make it better. We’re going to make it a lot better.”

MORE FROM JERRY: The governor delved more into his conversations with Trump during an appearance on “Face the Nation,” saying that while he raised how climate change has fanned the flames “I didn't feel that that was where we needed to go."

-- “We need the money, we need federal help and we need a collaborative and cooperative spirit and we're getting that,” Brown said, and he predicted California and the feds could find more common ground:

-- “We're going to look at all the elements that are causing these fires over time and we're going to work in a way to let science be our guide, and the president in no way negated that,” Brown said, adding that “I think over the next months and years you'll see the science becoming crystal clear, and even the folks in Washington that are now more in the denialist camp are going to come around.”

He said on Friday that wouldn’t factor into his decision — and he hinted at what it might look like for a national candidate to highlight the issue.

-- “If one of us were president,” Garcetti said at a CalMatters housing alongside Sacramento Mayor Darrell, San Diego Mayor Kevin Faulconer and Oakland Mayor Libby Schaaf, “this would be a priority in this country…Don’t require the mayors of this country to be the cleanup crew for a collective national failure to deal with the sources of why these things happen.”

GAVINLAND
